feedback:
Excellent application of the DRIVER framework throughout your work. You clearly demonstrated 6 stages: D, R, I, V, E, R2.


STRENGTHS:
- Financial APP: The student demonstrates a functioning financial application by describing specific financial data sources, risk-calculation tools, and outputs (metrics, VaR, Sharpe, scenario comparisons) and shows iterative improvement of the tool. These details across Discover/Implement/Reflect stages provide substantive evidence the tool performs financial tasks, meeting PASS standards.
- Integrate AI: The submission shows substantive, functional AI integration—multiple distinct AI/data components are connected and produce actionable outputs (metrics, risk assessment, recommendations). The student also demonstrates implementation work and iterative refinement, supporting that AI adds real value rather than being superficial.

criteria.criterion_name: Financial APP: The tool functions as a financial application.
evidence: "Then we have the open A I chat model that provides us with the A I then a market data API tool that gives us market data, a risk calculator tool that calculates risk and a scenario comparison that can compare scenarios for us."
"at first it was not outputting a correct visual and then I output the worked with it to create a correct visual."

"What it tells us what it can do for for me real-time stock market analysis, livestock price tracking, market trend analysis, then advanced risk assessment, sharp ratios, value at risk, other things, stock comparison analysis, side-by-side stock comparisons, risk and return trade-off evaluations and contextual investment guidance."
criteria.driver_alignment:
Discover: framed the problem ("should I invest in this stock") and user goals.  
Implement: describes concrete components (market data API, risk calculator, scenario comparison) and outputs (investment metrics, risk assessment).  
Reflect: iterated to fix visuals, showing refinement and working functionality.
criteria.reasoning: The student demonstrates a functioning financial application by describing specific financial data sources, risk-calculation tools, and outputs (metrics, VaR, Sharpe, scenario comparisons) and shows iterative improvement of the tool. These details across Discover/Implement/Reflect stages provide substantive evidence the tool performs financial tasks, meeting PASS standards.

criteria.criterion_name: Integrate AI: The tool integrates AI capabilities effectively.
evidence: "Then we have the open A I chat model that provides us with the A I then a market data API tool that gives us market data, a risk calculator tool that calculates risk and a scenario comparison that can compare scenarios for us."

"So from this from what I just input. It provides me the investment metrics, the risk assessment, you know, potential outcomes it has for me and the conclusions and then also provides recommendations at the end."
"This is the project and it provides a understanding and solves the problem of asking the question of should I invest in this stock."
criteria.driver_alignment: Discover: student defines the problem ("should I invest in this stock") and user goals. Implement: describes concrete AI components (OpenAI chat model, market data API, risk calculator, scenario comparator) and outputs (metrics, risk assessment, recommendations). Reflect: notes iterative refinement with the AI to correct visuals, indicating active improvement of the AI integration.
criteria.reasoning: The submission shows substantive, functional AI integration—multiple distinct AI/data components are connected and produce actionable outputs (metrics, risk assessment, recommendations). The student also demonstrates implementation work and iterative refinement, supporting that AI adds real value rather than being superficial.
